metadata.title: The case against investing in machine learning | by Jeffrey Scholz | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: The case against investing in machine learning
metadata.description: The word on the street is if you don’t invest in ML as a company or become an ML specialist, the industry will leave you behind. The hype has caught on at all levels, catching everyone from…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: How to Implement Any Machine Learning Algorithm Project with 3 Lines of Code

all_paragraphs: The word on the street is if you don’t invest in ML as a company or become an ML specialist, the industry will leave you behind. The hype has caught on at all levels, catching everyone from undergrads to VCs. Words like “revolutionary,” “innovative,” “disruptive,” and “lucrative” are frequently used to describe ML.
Allow me to share some perspective from my experiences that will hopefully temper this enthusiasm, at least a tiny bit.
This essay materialized from having the same conversation several times over with interlocutors who hope ML can unlock a bright future for them.

I’m here to convince you that investing in an ML department or ML specialists might not be in your best interest. That is not always true, of course, so read this with a critical eye. Let us begin — here are seven reasons why investing in ML might not be a good idea:

FANG — Facebook Apple Netflix Google. The names invoke a sense of extraordinary success, and for a good reason. Yet, these companies dominated their industries before Andrew Ng’s launched his first ML lectures on Coursera. Here’s why:
The difference between “good enough” and “state-of-the-art” machine learning is significant in academic publications but not in the real world.

About once or twice a year, something pops into my newsfeed, informing me that someone improved the top 1 ImageNet accuracy from 86 to 87 or so. Our community enshrines state-of-the-art with almost religious significance, so this score’s systematic improvement creates an impression that our field is racing towards unlocking the singularity.

No-one outside of academia cares if you can distinguish between a guitar and a ukulele 1% better. Sit back and think for a minute. How much have marginally better ML algorithms affected your life? Did that extra book Amazon recommended to you change your life and make you start dumping all your paychecks on Amazon products? (Or were you going to do that already?) Does Instagram’s future depend more on its algorithms or TikTok’s strategy? Are you more likely to become a Disney Plus subscriber because of its content or the content recommendation?

What about the companies that use ML as a core product? Grammarly comes to mind. Even for them, their top-line revenue isn’t even driven by an incrementally better perplexity score on whatever transformer network they are using. Most of their success will depend on how aggressively they can onboard and retain users. Users aren’t going to suddenly abandon the product because a particular version of the algorithm is one percent worse at detecting repeated, repeated, repeated words words words (yes, that was intentional, and ironically, Grammarly premium didn’t catch this error!). Users will probably be far more impacted by how good they feel about the UI/UX experience and how many times people see their ads.

Consider Tesla also. Tesla has a rabid fan-base whose loyalty isn’t singularly dependent on the self-driving feature — perhaps one of the most significant breakthroughs that machine learning has enabled in the recent past. Even if Tesla stopped supporting self-driving, they would still be a wildly popular car company because of their environmental ethos, fun driving experience, and overall cool factor.

Businesses succeed because many disparate parts are doing their job well and in tandem. Sales, leadership vision, availability of capital, product decisions, regulatory environment, and competitor actions usually have far more impact on a business’s success than doing incrementally better on a machine learning algorithm buried somewhere on a cloud server.

Let me be clear: Bad ML can sometimes prevent a company from succeeding if it is tied to a core revenue source like product or ad recommendations. But the converse is not true — great ML does not ensure business success. The effect of having 1% better ML than your competitors will almost always be drowned out by the other dimensions of running a successful business.
Do not succumb to cargo cult thinking and invest in ML because the successful companies are doing it. They became successful and then invested heavily in machine learning — not the other way around.

Any reasonably tech-savvy person can upload an Excel spreadsheet to an autoML program in Google Cloud, Azure, or AWS. Assuming they didn’t make any catastrophic mistakes collecting the data, they can often get a reasonably well-performing model without any knowledge of coding or machine learning. Don’t believe me? Watch this three-minute video and judge for yourself. It’s simple enough that you can watch at double speed if you like.

Amazon et al. brag about a long list of companies being customers of Sagemaker and Rekognition — Amazon’s ML-as-a-service for nonspecialists (https://aws.amazon.com/sagemaker/groundtruth/customers/). That’s a lot of business impact accomplished by offloading the ML problems to someone else.

You can imagine that being a “Sagemaker specialist” is kind of a dead-end career because, realistically, all you do is upload data, click some buttons, and then twiddle your thumbs while waiting for the next set of data (I recognize that this is an oversimplification, and I expand on this later — my point is that it is not something that takes 40 hours a week to do). Successful companies know better than to hire someone full time for a role like that. My argument works like this:

Now, of course, not all ML use-cases can be solved by an existing cloud offering. But the trend is inexorably headed towards commoditizing more and more ML use cases while being easier and easier to use.

Ah, but what if you have a predilection to actually writing code yourself? This article’s descriptive title should drive the point home: How to Implement Any Machine Learning Algorithm Project with 3 Lines of Code. What if you want a perfectly good object detector? Unfortunately, you’ll have to write two more lines. Want state of the art? Well, it’s here for you to copy and paste — with instructions for how to run it!

I’ll document it more in the next section, but the difference between off-the-shelf and state-of-the-art is often trivially small — and in many real-world applications, non-existent. The obsession with state of the art is mostly a social phenomenon, not one driven by business needs.
The fact of the matter is, reasonably smart people can use perfectly good ML algorithms with minimal effort.

Just hit up your favorite search engine and ask it “how I got into machine learning” and read some life stories. You’ll see that acquiring the skill is just a matter of determination and time. Still, the effort involved for an already technical person is quite a bit less than the effort needed to acquire a four-year degree or achieve near-native fluency in a difficult language like Arabic or Cantonese. Contrary to popular perception, training existing engineers in ML is extremely doable.

Numerous technical stakeholders have admitted to me in private that they use linear models or handcrafted rules in critical junctures of their systems. But they aren’t confessing it to me the way an ashamed person would. They usually accompany it with an annoyance that people who pushed machine learning on them couldn’t make better-performing systems.

The fact of the matter is, when ML fails to improve on something, that failure doesn’t make the news. Thus, we suffer from an availability bias about how often fancy machine learning actually accomplishes something compared to something simpler.

You’d be surprised at how many of the quantitative trading shops in Chicago rely primarily on logistic regression to make a buy or no buy signal. Plenty of websites with a search feature still use something vaguely similar to simple term matching.

I myself had deployed simple models when something fancier was an option, but there is a good reason for this. Linear models and decision trees are explainable, easy to debug, work when you have small to medium data, and allow intelligent humans to inject domain knowledge directly into them. Additionally, linear models and decision trees can be maintained by an outsider if I get hit by a bus.
Consider the following real-world machine learning examples where advanced deep learning is obviously a bad investment, despite AI peddlers having an obvious incentive to prove otherwise.

The Criteo dataset was a contest launched on Kaggle in 2014 (https://www.kaggle.com/c/criteo-display-ad-challenge). The competition was to predict if a user would click an ad. Back then, deep learning wasn’t really a thing. Contestants were evaluated on the log loss metric (the lower, the better). The winner came out on top with a score of 0.44463 using factorization machines (sounds fancy, but it’s basically just linear algebra).

Of course, deep learning researchers became interested in the dataset later, and various papers were published to improve on the score. Researchers from the almighty Google published a paper about a fancy deep learning architecture called Deep and Cross. Their log loss was 0.4419 — a tiny improvement of 0.00273. Fast forward another three years to today, and the best score is 0.4395. That’s millions of dollars spent on researcher salaries for an improvement of 0.00513 over the past six years since the dataset was released. A manager who balked at investing in deep learning to solve click prediction ought to be looking pretty smart in retrospect.

The Criteo dataset is about one terabyte large. I presume the gap between the old solution in 2014 and state of the art today would be much more significant if the dataset was bigger than one Terabyte. But how many companies have meaningful tabular datasets bigger than one Terabyte?
In Google’s case, a 0.00273 improvement might mean something. But it is a rounding error for the vast majority of us.

This dataset was released around 1994 by the University of California, Irvine. The goal was to predict if a person makes over $50,000 a year, given about 14 features about an individual (age, gender, country of origin, occupation, etc.). It has about 32,000 data points in it. This is actually useful in the real world — many companies have less than 30,000 customers, and many are interested in predicting their income or similar features. Can deep learning help you here? I’ve looked around, and I haven’t seen any papers on deep learning trying to beat a gradient boosted decision tree. The dataset is realistically large at 32,000 records, but not large enough for a neural network to outperform. The fact of the matter is, it’s hard to do better than a simple gradient-boosted decision tree in this case.

It might seem funny for me to list something here where deep learning has made steady progress, but I want to point out the sheer amount of capital that has been spent over the past five years to make neural networks 10% better. You can see the plot of how well we’ve done on Imagenet over time here (https://paperswithcode.com/sota/image-classification-on-imagenet).

Since 2016, we’ve gone from 78% accuracy to 88% accuracy. That’s no doubt, meaningful. Google has driven many of the advances here, and on average, the paper Google publishes on these breakthroughs has about ten or so authors. Given that a top-of-the-line ML researcher earns well over 500k per year, Google is spending about 5 million dollars per year just on the salaries to bump the image classifier up 1%. That’s not including computing cost (and trust me, it’s really high!) or the salaries of the researchers who tried to beat ImageNet and failed or the workers whose names didn’t make it to the paper’s authors list because they were doing grunt work. It’s not hard to imagine that Google is spending over $100 million per year for a 1% increase in performance on ImageNet.
How many companies can feasibly spend $100 million per year for a 1% bump in performance?
So, yes, massive investments in bleeding-edge deep learning research win the accuracy benchmark but badly lose on the economics benchmark.
I personally could be happy with spending a lot less on an intern to try some off-the-shelf image classifiers versus dumping millions into a department that will only give me a marginal improvement.
I actually don’t have to estimate how much Google is spending on ML innovation in the more flashy examples because a lot of this information is public.

Two of the famous leaders in AI innovation thankfully have more or less public financials. I’m thinking of DeepMind (now owned by Google) and OpenAI. OpenAI has made some cool stuff. It won Dota 2 against top-notch human players (although it did not solve the game in its full complexity). They also created GPT-3, which can create impressive writing that is hard to distinguish from human work. How much did this cost OpenAI? Since it is a non-profit, you can easily pull up their IRS 990 forms. Here is the breakdown of expenses by year:

These are tens of millions of dollars and multiplying. In fact, OpenAI is switching away from the non-profit model because they realize it’s simply not possible to sustain their output without a more reliable source of capital than the goodness of donors’ hearts. And I can’t blame the donors. Who would want to fund an operation whose expenses double every year with no end in sight?

DeepMind’s expenses are even more mind-boggling. DeepMind lost $572 million in 2018 and accrued over a billion dollars of debt by 2019. Now, don’t get me wrong, DeepMind has made some impressive ML innovations in game playing, medicine, and energy saving. However, the bill for that hasn’t broken even, and there is hardly any assurance that it ever will.

Oh, I’m just getting started here! What about IBM Watson? The info isn’t public, but one of their consultants publicized an estimate. For three years of development, the bill came out to about a billion dollars in 2010 to build the Jeopardy winning system (that’s a billion dollars in 2010, not 2020!). Whatever it has been since then is certainly not cheap! I can’t declare IBM Watson a failure before history has been written, but so far, it certainly hasn’t helped IBM dethrone one of the FANG companies as a dominant tech player — not an unreasonable ask for such a gargantuan investment.

It’s easy to look at these companies and wish that yours had something close to their level of innovation. But being jealous of other companies’ ML breakthroughs without considering the financial costs is like being jealous of someone who has a Ferrari in their driveway and not realizing they are drowning in debt to keep the collector away.

These organizations have the charter to unlock generalized AI, or at least create totally new solutions. The trouble is we have no idea how much work it takes to accomplish those goals, assuming we even can. Having an unconstrained charter leads to unconstrained expenses. Don’t do this unless you have the cash Google or IBM has.
Don’t start an ML department and say, “Innovate something for me!” You simply cannot estimate the cost involved, and the strategy is hopelessly vulnerable to the planning fallacy.

Now, of course, those fancy transformer networks (BERT, anyone?) have their place. I’m not disputing that. But even in that case, you don’t need PhDs from MIT to utilize them. Huggingface is probably the most known implementation: https://github.com/huggingface/transformers. By the way, you’ll need about six lines of code to experiment with it, which is more than in the last section. But let’s be fair, you do have to put in a little extra effort for something close to state of the art!
Are you noticing a trend here? ML, even the fancy stuff, is becoming simpler and simpler to use. But that happens to all evolving technologies, which leads me to the next section.

It used to be the case that if you wanted to use SQL, you needed to hire a database administrator. If you wanted to host a website, you needed to hire a systems administrator, a network administrator, and a Rackspace engineer. Believe it or not, a compiler engineer was a standard part of a software company many moons ago because machine instructions were not as standardized as they are today. You also needed an operating system specialist for the same reason! If you wanted to stream video, you’d better be ready to have someone who can invent their own video protocol and implement it in C++ because WebRTC, with its out-of-the-box Javascript APIs, didn’t exist back then.

Nowadays, if you want to stream video, you can call some Javascript APIs or pay a small fee to some SaaS company. If you want a database, you just click a few buttons on your favorite cloud provider. You don’t even think about compilers and operating systems anymore because those were standardized even before some of my readers were born. If you told someone today that your company has a compiler department, most engineers would look at you funny.

Of course, there are specialists who work in networks, databases, compilers, and so forth. Nonetheless, those roles are increasingly rare and relegated to companies where economies of scale and unique needs make the specialization economical. ML is not exempt from this trend that has repeated itself over and over.
Can you imagine what happens when you have a silo around a commoditizing technology? On to the next section.
The danger of silos is that outdated solutions stay around far too long in your company and cause inefficient waste.

The next time you have a beer with a software engineer, ask about what ridiculous inefficiencies still exist in the engineering department. The number one thing I hear is using a proprietary solution where an open-source or cloud solution exists. Once specialists gain political power in a company, they are very hard to dislodge even when it makes economic sense to replace them with something cheaper. Admittedly, some specializations are unavoidable, but I argue that ML is probably not one of them for many situations. Be wary of narrow charters because they incentivize people to reinvent the wheel to keep their job.

If you create the silo, make it clear that they must first look for external solutions before building something themselves. Stress that their charter is first and foremost to be an expert of existing solutions. Whatever you are trying to do, there is an excellent chance someone else had encountered that problem before and solved it. That is doubly true, now that billions of dollars have been poured into ML solutions.

Also, silos are naturally rewarded for becoming a solution looking for a problem. They have a bad incentive to add unnecessary features to products simply because that feature uses the technology they develop.

Even if they are well-meaning, it’s too easy to pigeonhole ML specialists into spending their time improving the accuracy of some system by a few percentage points. But does your business benefit from a 1% gain break even with the salaries you are paying those ML specialists? This applies whether the silo is one person, an entire department, or something in between.

A more economical solution is to roll out an ML model, monitor it, then revisit it in a year when some other researchers advance the state-of-the-art. This solution doesn’t work well if you have a machine learning silo because silos have low utilization with spiky work.

The stereotype works something like this. A full-stack team consists of a couple of ML scientists, some backend engineers, and maybe some front-end engineers, if applicable. The ML scientist develops the model and hands it to the backend engineer, who puts the model into an API. The new feature is launched, and the team pops the bottle of champagne. As time passes, the ML scientist monitors the model’s performance and updates it from time to time as more data is collected from instrumentation.
Because of how seductively simple this is, it looks compelling when presented to executives, and people outside the field think this is how things really operate.

Except that this is a very inefficient way to run things in reality, as I alluded to previously. Under this setup, the ML specialist and the backend engineers take turns twiddling their thumbs waiting for each other. Of course, they don’t actually twiddle their thumbs. They fill their time with low-value work simply to stay busy and not lose their job.

Building the initial ML model is a full-time job, yes, but it is a limited engagement. Maintaining it is barely a part-time job. In fact, right after the model launches, what will the ML specialist do in the following days while new data is being collected?

In reality, there are many open source and proprietary products for creating and hosting models that the spikes can be offloaded to. Here is a nice list if my refrain to Sagemaker is getting tiresome: https://neptune.ai/blog/best-mlops-tools (I’m not recommending neptune.ai, having never used it before, but I like the list they assembled on that page).

To really picture this in your mind’s eye, imagine you had a database specialist who only did work every time you needed to add the column, backup the database, or add a new query. Maybe every so often, that employee pops in to see if the database should be re-sharded.

This person would not be very busy, right? Hopefully, you aren’t changing your database that often as the product matures, and I would hope for the same with your ML model, which at best gets 1% better every year. Wouldn’t it be more economical to train your engineers to be decent at database management? The same applies to ML in a lot of cases.

New algorithms make the news and give the impression that success in ML development is about coming up with new algorithms. That is not the case, of course. We use existing algorithms 99.9% of the time.

Two things drive success with known algorithms: understanding your data (cleaning and exploring) and manipulating it in a way to make it more understandable to existing algorithms (feature engineering).

Both of these are a bit of an art form. If you look at most data science contests, you’ll see that people are usually using the same algorithms. But the winner is determined by who had the most brilliant insight into the data and could leverage that insight to make the off-the-shelf algorithm sensitive to it. The more people who look at your problem, the more likely a brilliant insight is to surface.

(I should make an aside here about contests: like state-of-the-art in research, it is not a good idea to be obsessed with the very best solution. Oftentimes, the difference between the first-place score and 100th place score is 1% — something that again usually doesn’t matter in the real world)

This doesn’t mean you should hire a hundred ML engineers to maximize your chance of success. It means either hire a consultant to find those insights for you (and then write five lines of code) or train your workforce on how to look for these insights and have everyone temporarily drop what they are doing to work on the ML problem temporarily. This is compatible with the spiky nature of ML.

This is a very realistic solution. ML is fun! I would have quit my job by now if that wasn’t the case. Your engineers will enjoy it, and you will save a lot of money. They also get to brag to their friends that they work on AI.

Machine learning development is a little different from software engineering. Software engineering doesn’t benefit from having too many people work on the same section of the code. It creates opportunities for miscommunication, and it’s hard to measure who did what.
On the other hand, machine learning development works extremely well in parallel because you can easily combine models or modeling techniques at the end (we call that ensembling).

Furthermore, worker output is literally measurable with the accuracy score of the models they produce. You actually know who contributed what with a cold hard number, despite having many people working on it. You get metrics-based management with an uncontrived metric that actually matters. It doesn’t get any better than that!

I’m not prophesying that ML services will make engineers — ML ones or in general — obsolete someday. Such a prediction is not supported by current trends and is little better than science fiction and idle speculation. I am pointing out that, although the ML engineer will not die completely, it will be less and less necessary as time goes by.

However, it’s still absolutely worth knowing the subject for practical edification because having the skills to execute machine learning and data science makes you a better technologist and decision-maker in general, even if you don’t use this skill exclusively on a day to day basis.

For example, even though there are plenty of software engineers who don’t know anything about the physics of silicon and transistors, but they do know key information about hardware, namely that RAM is faster than disk, the CPU has a fixed number of cores, sequential reads on hard disks are faster than random seeks, and network packets drop from time to time. They may not understand the exact mechanics of why these phenomena exist, but they can intelligently make decisions around these matters.
You don’t need to be a network specialist to write a good API, but you can’t be completely ignorant about networks.
You don’t need to know how the ext4 format works to write and read data from a disk, but you should understand that writing is slower than reading.
You don’t need to be a database specialist to use SQL as part of your app, but you should know about the CAP theorem and the difference between eventually consistent and strongly consistent.

There are analogs for machine learning. You don’t need to know exactly when XGBoost decides to split or what the parameters beta1 and beta2 in the Adam optimizer do. Still, you should know about the gotchas of ML and statistics like underfitting/overfitting, reversion to the mean, non-stationary distributions, seasonality, heteroskedasticity, correlation/causation, ergodicity, outliers, dirty data, data leakage, class imbalance, not outperforming a baseline, and discounting common sense and domain knowledge. (Anything else I should add to the list? Please comment below)

Some of those terms may seem scary to the uninitiated, but wouldn’t something like left-join, SELECT *, indexing, sharding, secondary key, and foreign key also sound mysterious at first? The fact of the matter is, they really are quite learnable. Just because database terms aren’t enshrouded in sociological herd hype doesn’t make them less technically interesting or complicated.

Ignorance can definitely hurt you. Blindly trusting an ML algorithm that you got from thoughtlessly plugging your data into is obviously bad. However, you don’t need a Ph.D. or even a master’s to avoid these silly outcomes, just as you don’t need to know how the Google Chrome Javascript engine works inside-out to write a web app. It’s all about balance and not investing past the point of diminishing returns. And in my experience, the point of diminishing returns comes quickly.

ML is evolving at quite a fast pace, but outdated truths about it aren’t dying at the same rate. Training ImageNet from scratch was crazy six years ago, but nowadays, it can be done cheaply in less than 20 minutes. Yet, many people still think training from scratch is too computationally expensive. You used to need specialized knowledge to build a simple neural network because Caffe and Tensorflow version zero were truly nightmarish to use. But nowadays, you can copy six lines of code from a Medium or Stackoverflow post. Similarly, if this essay were written four years ago, it would have been laughably wrong.

Having successfully led non-ML software engineers to create high impact ML models and having guided startups to accomplish their ML goals without hiring ML engineers or expensive consulting firms, I can assure you that the need for ML specialists is far smaller than the current hype is making it out to be.

So yes, your engineers can’t be ignorant about data science, ML, statistics, AI, or whatever you want to call it. But most teams can still drive a lot of business value without a set of specific team members dedicating their career exclusively to it. Even if they try and fail, you will be in a position to evaluate ML talent or solutions more effectively afterward.

Find startups who solve the problem you have on hand and offload your specific ML problem to them while paying them a lot less than an ML scientist’s salary. As more and more competitors come in, renegotiate the prices in your favor. Don’t hire someone that you will only need for a few quarters. Technology inevitably becomes cheaper as time goes by. You want to be a customer in this market, not a seller. Commoditization is ruthless.

Use off-the-shelf solutions. You’ll get something within striking distance of state of the art, but your expenditures will be massively cheaper. Keep yourself up to date with what AWS and its competitors are offering. Set up multiple sales calls to see what potential partners can do for you. You will soon get a sense of which ML services are standard.

Have your engineers take online courses for ML and get educational feedback by participating in data science competitions relevant to your business needs. You may have a slight dip in productivity in the short term but a massive gain in retention, engagement, and worker efficiency in the medium and long term. Don’t expect them to become experts in 3 months. However, making consistent incremental progress yields tremendous results.

Please note that I’m not saying this is an “either-or” concerning having an ML specialist or not. Some hybrid models where someone is ultimately responsible for ML outcomes but also expected to coordinate ML from nonspecialists can work well.

Deep learning only pays off when you have a tremendous amount of data at your disposal. When you only have a small or medium amount of data, simple models work well. As you grow, collect data in a clean way, but don’t be obsessed with state-of-the-art predictive analytics just yet. When you achieve ultra-scale, then it can make economic sense to hire expensive ML experts and squeeze out the last couple percent where it matters.

This essay is a plea to decision-makers to allocate resources wisely. It is also a stern warning to students and potential converts against overspecialization in a field evolving against the need for specialization, as happens with most technology stacks.

There are so many boot camps and masters programs ready to push their newly minted ML specialists on you (or issue a siren call to pay them big tuition fees). There are enough ML consultants ready to charge you a lot of money for what you could get cheaply on the cloud (pro tip: Ask a quote for an ML model you know AWS provides cheaply and see if they try to bill you to build a system without mentioning AWS). Please, take a step back and look at your business. Is having ML that is 1% better really what is holding your company, department, or team back from greatness? Oftentimes, the answer is no.
Again, I’ll need to say this repeatedly — my claim here is not universally true. However, the commentary on machine learning nowadays is so lopsidedly bullish that a valid counterpoint is needed.
I should explicitly state what I believe is implied in the essay above:

Again, it is not universally true that companies or company departments don’t need ML specialists. My point is, don’t create an ML department just because it’s ML. There should be an obvious economic reason to allocate resources this way. And if you do have a genuine ML need, look at the alternatives before committing to pay massive salaries. And if you must invest, think carefully about the scope of the charter. But isn’t that true of any business investment? Hype doesn’t make timeless business truths go away.

Yeah, I can’t argue with this one, but I do want to acknowledge that it exists. If you have a legitimate need and you can’t get your current workforce to expand their skills, then yes, it’s probably worth bringing her in even if she only has to do real work for 15 hours a week.

I’m assuming you weren’t turned off by the high costs I documented earlier. Large companies have departments whose sole job is to create something impressively innovative using ML, like a machine that can play games above human capabilities, create a convincing fake video, write coherent essays from scratch, etc. Here’s the thing though: companies that do this can afford to burn billions of dollars on incredibly low probability investments. Nearly all of these efforts go nowhere, but as a courtesy of survivorship bias, you only hear about the few successes. People pay lip service to “celebrating failure,” but when was the last time you saw a press release from Facebook about giving up on some AI project that turned out to be infeasible?

Furthermore, big tech companies get an intangible benefit from creating spectacular ML outcomes even if they lead to no direct business value, because it creates the brand image of being an innovative company. This is true even if the rest of the company is stodgy and un-innovative. Things haven’t really changed due to Lee Sedol being defeated by AlphaGo, but it definitely made Google look cool and maybe tipped the decision for some talent to join Google instead of someone else.

This perception keeps the investors interested and attracts talent to the company, often to the boring jobs that actually drive value. However, investing in ML because maybe, just maybe, that ML department will develop an innovation that makes the company dominate the industry is almost like buying lottery tickets. Chances are, your company doesn’t have enough cash to gamble like that.
Don’t extrapolate regular advances in a benchmark to the hope that totally new use-cases can be unlocked.

Also, why do some believe that ML has a monopoly on innovation? Apple is widely considered an innovative company, but they have famously been behind on technology adoption. They innovated on UI/UX and became a trillion-dollar company because of it. Innovation is important, of course, but it doesn’t have to be in ML!

Don’t try to forge innovation out of thin air. Necessity is the mother of invention (innovation), not the other way around. Start with a problem worth solving and work backward. If you end up with a “boring” solution, so be it. You’ve still made the world a better place. But you should never start with a solution and work forward.

I couldn’t fit this video into the flow of point two, but it needs to be included in this article, so I’ve added it here. It brilliantly illustrates a consultant’s experience using simple models in production — something that is simply not talked about enough.

This aged well! Three months after this piece was originally published (November 17, 2020), the Wall Street Journal reported that IBM is seeking to sell of Watson Health (https://www.wsj.com/articles/ibm-explores-sale-of-ibm-watson-health-11613696770) due to a lack of profitability.
I’ve also found a couple of interesting pieces on Forbes that echo the same points I made in this article.
